content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 42$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 42$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 12$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. Append your choice letter in curly brackets as a last character.

As a human player, I would analyze the payoff structure of this game to determine my strategy. The payoffs suggest that choosing R yields a higher payoff when the opponent chooses B (42$ compared to 0$), but if both players choose R, they each get 45$. On the other hand, choosing B results in a higher payoff only when the opponent chooses R (12$ compared to 0$). However, if both players choose B, they each earn 12$.

Since this is a repeated game with 75 rounds, I would consider the long-term benefits of my strategy. Choosing B consistently would result in lower payoffs (12$ per round) but less risk since the opponent might pick R and get a higher payoff if I choose B as well. On the other hand, choosing R more frequently could potentially lead to larger individual payoffs (up to 45$) but also increased risk due to potential losses when the opponent picks R too.

Considering these factors, my strategy would be to choose R only in some rounds and mix it with B choices to minimize the risk of losing money overall while still having a chance at receiving higher payoffs. In other words, I would adopt a mixed strategy that doesn't favor one choice over the other. {R or B}

However, it is essential to note that I cannot predict my opponent's behavior, so my optimal strategy will depend on their choices as well. If I observe that they consistently pick R, for example, I might choose B more often to avoid losing money. Conversely, if they choose B more frequently, I would consider picking R more often. Ultimately, the best approach is likely a combination of both strategies based on the observed patterns during the game rounds.
